I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed equity 
investment of up to $25,000,000 in ATH International Venture Pte Limited (Singapore) (ATHIV) 
for the Pacific Telecommunications Modernization Project in Papua New Guinea (PNG). 
 
2.  Amalgamated Telecom Holdings Limited (Fiji) (ATH), through its wholly owned special-
purpose vehicle ATHIV, is raising equity to partially fund its $404.5 million telecommunication 
venture in PNG. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) will be a cornerstone investor in ATHIV, 
and its $25 million equity investment will support the establishment of Vodafone PNG as a new 
telecommunication operator that will provide increased and improved mobile, broadband, and 
internet services in PNG. The provision of reliable and affordable telecommunication services will 
benefit PNG’s underserved population, leading to greater socioeconomic growth and poverty 
reduction. 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Project Identification and Description 
 
3.  Project identification. Universal access to telecommunication infrastructure is critical to 
any  country’s  socioeconomic  development.  Increased  mobile and  internet  connections  can 
(i) improve access to domestic and regional markets for traders, manufacturers, and business 
owners; (ii) increase access to education, finance, telemedicine, and government services; and 
(iii) facilitate communication between rural and urban communities. PNG, with a population of 9.3 
million, is the region’s largest yet least-developed telecommunication market.1 PNG’s internet 
prices are among the highest in the world, with 55% of internet services still connected to 2G, 
followed by 23% to 3G, and only 22% to 4G. The mobile penetration rate is 32% and internet 
penetration rate is 11% of the total population.2 Low penetration rates and high prices are a 
consequence of low bandwidth capacity, underinvestment in technology, and lack of market 
competition that have resulted in pent up demand for affordable and quality mobile and data 
services in PNG. 
 
4.  PNG’s telecommunication market is presently serviced by two operators—Digicel (PNG) 
Limited and Bemobile–Telikom (Kumul Telikom Holdings)—although Digicel’s 92% mobile market 
share  effectively  makes  it  a  quasi-monopoly  in  PNG  (footnote  2). 3  [CONFIDENTIAL 
INFORMATION DELETED] 
 
5.  Given the current state of PNG’s telecommunication industry, the market is ripe for a 
disruptive new entrant that can realize PNG’s untapped potential and feed the latent demand for 
quality telecommunication services. Other factors supporting the entry of a new market participant 
include (i) a favorable regulatory regime that aims to promote market competition; (ii) strong 
demand for high-speed data, especially from retail consumers and corporate enterprises in urban 
centers; and (iii) increasing deployment of national and international fiber optic cables and 
satellites such as Kacific5, Coral Sea Cable, and Kumul Submarine Cable that will provide high-
speed international bandwidth at much lower costs.  
                                                
1  Global System for Mobile Communication Association (GSMA). 2019. Digital Transformation: The Role of Mobile 
Technology in Papua New Guinea. London. 
2  Global System for Mobile Communication Association. 2019. Digital Transformation: The Role of Mobile Technology 
in Papua New Guinea. London.  (March). 
3  ADB. 2009. Papua New Guinea: Digicel Mobile Telecommunication Expansion Project; and ADB. 2011. Bemobile 
Expansion Project (Papua New Guinea and the Solomon Islands).  
5  ADB. 2019. Asia–Pacific Remote Broadband Internet Satellite Project.

2 
 
6.  ATH, with its telecommunication operations in six Pacific markets, has been conducting 
extensive due diligence on PNG’s telecommunication industry since 2013, when it considered the 
acquisition of Bemobile.6 In 2018, ATH set up ATHIV in Singapore to raise capital for its new PNG 
venture.  
 
[CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED] 
 
7.  Project description. 
 
[CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED] 
 
10.  Investee and sponsor description. The investee, ATHIV, is a special-purpose vehicle 
set up by ATH to roll out its PNG venture. ATH, the project sponsor, pioneered 4G+ technology 
in Fiji and has extensive experience in the Pacific telecommunication market. ATH’s recent 
regional telecommunication acquisitions include Kiribati Telecom Services (in 2015); Vanuatu 
Telecom (in 2017); BlueSky Group operations in Samoa, Cook Islands, and American Samoa (in 
2018 and 2019); and Digitec Communications Limited (in 2019). ATH is a publicly listed company 
on the South Pacific Stock Exchange, with market capitalization of approximately $380 million (as 
of July 2020). While ATH is the project sponsor, the project will be managed by ATH’s subsidiary, 
Vodafone Fiji Limited—Fiji’s largest telecommunication operator which holds 81% of Fiji’s mobile 
market.10 [CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED] 
 
12.  ADB  conducted  enhanced  tax  integrity  due  diligence.  ADB  obtained  reasonable 
assurances that relevant entities were not established or are being used for money laundering or 
terrorism financing in the project jurisdiction, and that the transaction is not being used for tax 
secrecy, tax evasion, or tax fraud, with the tax integrity risks being low and acceptable. 
 
B.  Development Impact, Outcome, and Outputs 
 
13.  Impact. The project is aligned with the following impact: reach of modern and affordable 
ICT across PNG improved. 
 
14.  Outcome.  The  project  will  have  the  following  outcome:  penetration  of  high-quality, 
reliable, and affordable mobile telecommunication services in the country increased.16 
 
15.  Outputs. The project has the following outputs: (i) telecommunication towers are installed, 
(ii) Vodafone PNG’s 4G network rolled out, (iii) gender-inclusive local employment is generated, 
(iv) gender equality of Vodafone PNG product offering is enhanced, (v) Vodafone PNG becomes 
a  more  gender-inclusive  work  environment,  and  (vi)  gender-inclusive  corporate  social 
responsibility program is developed by Vodafone PNG. 
 
C.  Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 
 
                                                
6  Following PNG’s 2011 constitutional crisis, Bemobile’s financial and operating performance suffered greatly. In a 
“White Knight” rescue attempt, the Fiji National Provident Fund offered to acquire Bemobile in 2013. This offer was 
ultimately rejected when Telikom PNG fully acquired Bemobile in 2015. In 2019, ADB and ATH commissioned two 
independent consultants, Kitskoo and Gibson Quai International, to conduct market and technical due diligence for 
the PNG venture. The results of their due diligence were submitted to ADB in January 2020. 
10 Amalgamated Telecom Holdings Limited and Subsidiary Companies. 2019. 2019 Annual Report. Suva. 
16 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

3 
16.  ADB’s Strategy 203017 recognizes the unique development challenges facing Pacific small 
island developing states, including PNG, and has a special focus on increasing private sector 
investment in these countries. In line with ADB’s Strategy 2030 and its country partnership 
strategy for Papua New Guinea, 2016–2020,18 this project helps to improve livelihoods and 
enhance digital connectivity for the most poor and vulnerable sections of society, while also 
improving PNG’s business environment through private sector development. The project supports 
operational priority 1 (addressing remaining poverty and reducing inequalities) as it will generate 
jobs for local people living in rural and urban areas in PNG. Job creation within local communities 
will provide stable earnings and help to bridge inequality between rural and urban populations. 
This project strongly supports operational priority 2 (accelerating progress in gender equality) as 
it increases economic empowerment of women through greater employment opportunities and 
improved access to ICT infrastructure. Through the development of anti-sexual-harassment and 
family violence support policies at Vodafone PNG, this project aims to address some of the vital 
issues regarding gender-based violence in PNG.19 This regional project supports operational 
priority 7 (fostering regional cooperation and integration) as it expands regional investment 
between Pacific countries. This venture is a regional collaboration between Fijian entities and 
institutional investors from Samoa and PNG. The project builds on ADB’s existing regional 
initiatives, including the recently approved Asia–Pacific Remote Broadband Internet Satellite 
Project (Kacific), which will complement Vodafone PNG’s ability to provide low-cost internet 
coverage to even the most remote locations on the island.

III.  THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  The Assistance 
 
24.  ADB’s $25 million equity will be funded from ADB’s ordinary capital resources and will be 
invested on pro-rata terms to acquire ordinary shares of ATHIV. [CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION 
DELETED] 
 
B.  Value Added by ADB Assistance 
 
25.  Support the inclusive development of Papua New Guinea’s telecommunication 
industry. PNG’s telecommunication industry is relatively undeveloped, with a vast majority of the 
population having little or no internet access. ADB’s equity investment will provide crucial capital 
for ATH’s venture in PNG, which will deliver quality telecommunication services to the population. 
Superior and affordable telecommunication services will not only facilitate greater communication 
within the country and region but also serve as a basic access tool for other sectors, such as 
health care, education, and finance.26 With ADB’s shareholding in ATHIV, and with an ADB 
nominee on the ATHIV board of directors, ATH and Vodafone PNG will gain valuable insights into 
best practices and lessons from ADB’s previous projects in the PNG telecommunication industry 
and in other comparable markets in Asia. 
 
26.  Catalyze private sector financing for Papua New Guinea. Obtaining private sector 
finance for PNG is challenging, but COVID-19 and the ensuing credit crunch complicated ATH’s 
capital raising. Thus, ADB’s investment at this time is both compelling and pivotal. The signaling 
effect and increased market confidence from ADB’s investment will greatly enhance ATH’s ability 
to raise debt and equity for this project. Furthermore, ADB’s role as cornerstone investor and 
arranger for this transaction will be of significant value to all investors. ADB has selected top-
notch expertise for the market, technical, financial, legal, and environmental and social due 
diligence aspects of this investment, which greatly benefits all shareholders. 
 
27.  Progress towards market-leading standards. As cornerstone investor, ADB will support 
Vodafone PNG’s adherence to high corporate governance and integrity standards, as well as the 
establishment of market-leading social and environmental standards, with demonstration effects 
in the PNG telecommunication industry. Further, ADB will enhance gender inclusivity at Vodafone 
PNG by improving gender balance and opportunities for women in the workplace.

IV.  POLICY COMPLIANCE 
 
A.  Safeguards and Social Dimensions 
 
31.  The investment is a general corporate finance transaction under Appendix 4 of ADB’s 
Safeguard Policy Statement (2009). ADB has categorized the investment in compliance with 
ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement as follows: environment category B, involuntary resettlement 
category C, and indigenous peoples category B.29 This categorization is based on the potential 
environmental and social impacts of the company’s existing and future telecommunication tower 
sites and project activities. 
 
32.  ADB has undertaken due diligence and reviewed the potential environmental and social 
(E&S) impact of the project and the measures to avoid, minimize, mitigate, and compensate for 
adverse impacts in the safeguard reports and plans.30 A corporate audit was undertaken by an 
external third party in accordance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement requirements. The 
audit comprised (i) a corporate audit of VFL’s existing E&S  procedures (as the recognized chief 
operating entity of ATHIV) that will be implemented in PNG; (ii) an audit of Vodafone PNG’s 
existing E&S processes and procedures in the absence of an existing environmental and social 
management system (ESMS), and implementation; and (iii) a review of compliance with national 
laws of Vodafone PNG’s identified existing procedures, sites, and facilities. 
 
33.  Audit findings and recommendations have been documented and agreed with ATHIV and 
VFL in a corrective action plan for the project. In line with the corrective action plan, Vodafone 
PNG will prepare an ESMS satisfactory to ADB requirements, building on existing Environmental 
and  Social  policies  and  procedures  of  Vodafone  PNG  and  VFL.  ATHIV  has  engaged  an 
accredited third-party consultant to undertake an initial environmental examination of the project 
and an environmental management framework plan and indigenous peoples plan to comply with 
ADB’s requirements and national regulations. The indigenous peoples plan will be disclosed prior 
to ADB’s first disbursement, and customary landowners will be consulted in accordance with the 
plan before construction at each tower site. Vodafone PNG will strengthen its environmental and 
social capacity. It will report semiannually to ADB regarding compliance with the ESMS and ADB’s 
Safeguard Policy Statement requirements. 
 
34.  Vodafone PNG will pay special attention to PNG’s more than 800 ethnic groups, which 
hold customary ownership of about 97% of all land. There will be no involuntary land acquisition, 
and all tower locations will be leased. Any transaction involving customary land will go through a 
culturally sensitive negotiation and engagement process, following a protocol developed in line 
with national regulations. Similarly, Vodafone PNG will develop a culturally sensitive grievance 
redress mechanism accessible to any affected indigenous peoples and customary landowning 
communities, including both men and women. The surrounding indigenous communities will be 
recruited during project construction and will also benefit from a number of social development 
programs implemented by Vodafone PNG through its corporate social responsibility program. 
 
35.  Effective gender mainstreaming. Following ADB’s Policy on Gender and Development, 
Vodafone  PNG  has  incorporated  measures  to  promote  gender  equality  and  women’s 
empowerment in its business activities.31 Digital gender gaps, gender-based income inequality, 
and gender-based violence are some of the crucial issues to be addressed in PNG. Through this

project, Vodafone PNG undertakes to include specific measures targeting women for employment 
opportunities, creating an inclusive and flexible work environment for women, developing training 
opportunities for women, and developing value-added services that help women report sexual 
harassment or family violence.32 
 
36.  ATHIV  and  its  subsidiary Vodafone  PNG  will  (i)  apply ADB's prohibited  investment 
activities list, (ii) ensure that investments using ADB funds comply with ADB’s Safeguard Policy 
Statement and abide by national laws and regulations, and (iii) establish and maintain an 
appropriate ESMS satisfactory to ADB before disbursement. The ESMS will set out requirements, 
as  applicable,  for  compliance  with  national  labor  laws  and  measures  to  comply  with  the 
internationally recognized core labor standards, pursuant to ADB’s Social Protection Strategy 
(2001). The ESMS will also contain requirements, as applicable, for information disclosure and 
consultation with affected people following ADB requirements. ATHIV will report regularly to ADB 
regarding (i) Vodafone PNG’s compliance with such laws and (ii) the measures taken.33 
 
B.  Anticorruption Policy 
 
37.  ATHIV and its subsidiary Vodafone PNG were advised of ADB’s policy of implementing 
best international practice relating to combating corruption, money laundering, and the financing 
of terrorism. ADB will ensure that the investment documentation includes appropriate provisions 
prohibiting corruption, money laundering, and the financing of terrorism; and remedies for ADB in 
the event of noncompliance. 
 
C.  Investment Limitations 
 
[CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED] 
 
D.  Assurances 
 
39.  Consistent with the Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank (the Charter),34 
ADB will proceed with the proposed assistance upon establishing that the Government of Fiji and 
the Government of PNG have no objection to the proposed assistance to ATHIV. ADB will enter 
into  suitable  finance  documentation,  in  form  and  substance  satisfactory  to  ADB,  following 
approval of the proposed assistance by the ADB Board of Directors. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
40.  I am satisfied that the proposed equity investment would comply with the Articles of 
Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB), and recommend that the Board approve the 
equity investment of up to $25,000,000 from ADB’s ordinary capital resources in ATH International 
Venture Pte Limited (Singapore) for the Pacific Telecommunications Modernization Project in 
Papua New Guinea, with such terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those 
set forth in this report, and as may be reported to the Board. 
 
 
Masatsugu Asakawa 
President

The Asian Development Bank (ADB) will be a cornerstone investor in ATHIV, and its $25 million equity investment will support the establishment of Vodafone PNG as a new telecommunication operator that will provide increased and improved mobile, broadband, and internet services in PNG. The provision of reliable and affordable telecommunication services will benefit PNG’s underserved population, leading to greater socioeconomic growth and poverty reduction.

The report and recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors (RRP) document describes the terms and conditions of a project for consideration and approval by ADB's Board of Directors.

This document dated August 2020 is provided for the ADB project 54204-001 in Papua New Guinea.
